bioghist.p: Founded in 1743 by Benjamin Franklin, the American Philosophical Society was the first learned society in the United States. For over 250 years, the Society has played an important role in American cultural and intellectual life. Until the mid-nineteenth century, the Society fulfilled the role of a national academy of science, national library and museum, and even patent office. Early members of the Society included Thomas Jefferson, David Rittenhouse, Benjamin Rush, Stephen Peter Du Ponceau, George Washington, and many other figures prominent in American history. Members of the Society may serve on various standing and ad hoc committees, formed over the Society's history to handle specific topics ranging from finance and grants to the Franklin Bicentenary and the construction of Library Hall.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of records of various committees of the American Philosophical Society. Records include minutes and supporting materials for the following committees: Committee on Finance (1933-1975 and 1986); Committee on Research (1936-1963); Committee on Hall (1986); Committee on the Library (1986); Committee on Meetings (1923-1971 and 1986); Committee on Nomination of Officers (1986); Committee on Publications (1940-1963); Advisory Committee on Election (1981-1986); Council minutes (1942 and 1948); and Stated Meeting of Council minutes (1916-1948). The collection also includes general information on committees, such as appointments and meeting dates, and miscellaneous topical files.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
